round 1 is completely unknown because the human eye only has one spot that it focuses on. a camera controller has to scan the entire image and figure out where the focus should be centered, then figure out the focal distance. a camera transplanted into a person would only have to worry about keeping the exact center in focus. much simpler.
round 2 is not a tie. your eye has the exact same problem as a camera. they both have to focus on and track a single object at a time, and are blurry when moved. the brain filters out that blur. as a matter of fact, it even edits your sense of time so you don't notice the missing instant between movements of your eyes.
round 3.. again, ridiculous. the color correction, combining of two images, etc., would still be done by the brain with the data fed to your brain from the camera.

- Can be placed all around the head (or anywhere) to effectively give 360 degree vision, where we could choose to see with a subset of cameras at any given time.
- Picture can be shared with others in real time.

If I replaced my eyes with a camera, they'd have the processing power of my brain, giving them all of the eye's advantages, and the camera's advantages. How could we surpass evolution? Well, evolution only goes forwards, and it goes by "survival of the fit enough". Eyes were originally developed in water, for water. Being able to see in the air is an adaptation of eyes that were originally designed for water. They were also not as optimised as our cameras, because you can't evolve a camera - cameras, unlike eyes, really are irreducible.

Cameras do have a couple significant advantages over eyes.
First, they can resolve images sharply over a wide field of view. While human eye resolution is pretty good at the fovea, it is terrible at the peripheries, and capturing all the details of a stationary scene requires the eyes to scan the fovea over each portion of the image.
Second, cameras have the crucial ability to flawlessly record and retrieve images they take. With enough memory, you can even do this continuously, recording almost every instant of time clearly. Human visual memory, on the other hand, is notoriously unreliable.
Third, cameras can change their settings at will, and can go from capturing multi-second exposures while stargazing to thousands of fps to track fast objects. The human perception is sort of stuck in a mid-range 20-60 fps.
Most important, Human eyes are integrated. We can add some external attachments like eyeglasses or contact lenses to improve them, but they are intrinsically non-modular. With a camera eye, you might be able to get special modules for high speed video or ultraviolet vision or real time telemetry. With eyes, you're lucky to just keep them as good as they were 20 years ago.
Now another question: What if you, instead of replacing your eyes with cameras, you just added cameras?

You missed a lot of points, and it's clear you didn't do much actual research. You picked one camera, and compared the eye to what it was capable of doing.
The main features of the eye are quick focusing, dynamic range, and "night vision".
The eye can very quickly focus from one object to another, but there are cameras such as the Canon 1D-C that have such impressive auto focusing, that it can track extremely fast moving objects effortlessly. The eye often has problems with this.
As for dynamic range, the eye probably is the winner, but there are cameras moving toward insane amounts of dynamic range, eventually, they'll surpass the eye.
Night vision, cameras such as the Sony a7s Mark ii can film at ISO levels so high, you can see even better than your eye can. This technology gets better all the time.
One thing that cameras will always win is high frame rates. High-speed cameras that can film super slow motion videos are something the eye will never be able to do.
The eye isn't much better than some of the best camera technologies out there. And that gap is closing all the time.

Back when I worked in optics for satellites, I came to the conclusion that human vision was the baseline for all camera development. But we needed to see detail at much greater distances which meant telescopes. So these days I am an amateur astronomer.
Now the human eye fails miserably in that field, even with the brain behind it. It is just too small with an aperture generally only about 7mm maximum. Also the brain cannot cope with long exposures as image extinction at the retina or the extent of persistence of vision is about 1/20th of a second.
Stars are very colorful but human vision renders them shades of grey with few exceptions among the very brightest. Standard professional photographic cameras, these days mostly in the 35mm equivalent range do stay open longer, can register those colors quite well, and only fail when not tracking the heavens well.
Amazingly, many camera phones today tend to more closely emulate the eye and its brain functions. the small aperture, combined with software and a similar field of view make the WYSYG work for them. (What You See, You Get for younger readers unused to the early days of word processing)

actually a lot of the advantages are coming from our brain. In theory, our brain should be able to adapt to the cameras and produce similar result especially the parts where the processing is one way and doesn't require the camera to react.

If you ONLY replaced your EYE with a camera lens and sensor, your brain would still be the processor/fuser for the information, and your muscles could still move the camera to look at what you were interested in. Thus you'd get similar dynamic range, slightly improved focus response, better global resolution (eyes only have high resolution in the middle of their view whereas cameras have constant pixel density), better speed/frame rate, and more wavelengths (if you wanted to see NIR, for instance). Replacing your brain with a camera microprocessor, however, is obviously a mistake.
